title: US envoy to Ukraine hails Zelenskyy as 'embattled and courageous leader'
body:
Keith Kellogg strikes different tone from Trump, who called Ukrainian president a 'dictator'
 The US envoy to Ukraine, Gen Keith Kellogg, has praised Voldymyr Zelenskyy as "the embattled and courageous leader of a nation at war", striking a dramatically different tone from Donald Trump who has called Ukraine's president a "dictator"
  Kellogg left Kyiv on Friday after a three-day visit. Posting on social media , he said he had had "extensive and positive discussions" with Zelenskyy and his "talented national security team". "A long and intense day with the senior leadership of Ukraine," he said.
  The general's upbeat remarks are in glaring contrast to those of the US president and his entourage, who have heaped abuse on Zelenskyy during a tumultuous week. Trump claimed Ukraine was to blame for starting the war with Russia, and accused Zelenskyy of doing "a terrible job".
  On Friday, Trump returned to the theme, saying he did not consider it essential for the Ukrainian president to be present at negotiations. "I don't think he's very important to be in meetings," Trump told Fox News. "He's been there for three years. He makes it very hard to make deals."
  The world's richest man, Elon Musk, who is leading Trump's huge governmental overhaul, said Trump was right to leave Zelenskyy out of peace talks with Russia , held in the Saudi capital, Riyadh. Without evidence, Musk accused Ukraine's leader of running a "massive graft machine feeding off the dead bodies of Ukrainian soldiers".
  Kellogg is known to be the most pro-Ukrainian of Trump's senior team. Nevertheless, the difference in rhetoric suggests a chaotic and contradictory approach to foreign policy, from a White House that has dumped Ukraine as an ally and publicly sided with Moscow.
  Zelenskyy prompted Trump's ire by observing that the US president lived in a Kremlin " disinformation bubble ". Despite their disagreement, there were signs on Friday that US and Ukrainian negotiators are coming closer to making a deal over Ukraine's vast mineral resources.
  Late last year, Zelenskyy floated the idea of a partnership with the US. He was surprised when the US treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, asked him to sign an agreement that would give the White House $500bn (£395bn) in natural resources, as "payback" for previous US military assistance.
  Zelenskyy declined to sign the document without US security guarantees, to enforce any postwar settlement with Russia. There were reports on Friday that talks over US preferential access to Ukraine's critical resources were ongoing, with drafts being constantly swapped.
  "We sent another one yesterday," one Kyiv source told the AFP news agency, adding that Ukraine was now waiting for a US response. On Friday, the White House national security adviser, Mike Waltz , said he expected the Ukrainian government "in a very short time" to sign the "rare earth" deal.
  Trump's crude verbal criticism of Ukraine and his repetition of Russian talking points have stunned and alarmed European leaders. Nearly a dozen of them have called Zelenskyy over the last 48 hours, offering support for a just and sustainable end to the war, and reaffirming shared democratic values.
  They include Keir Starmer and France's president, Emmanuel Macron, both of whom will visit Washington next week . In an address to France, Macron said he would tell Trump: "You can't be weak with [Vladimir] Putin." Poland's conservative president, Andrzej Duda, who is due to meet Trump in Washington on Saturday, said Zelenskyy should stay calm and cooperate.
  Several senior Europeans will visit Kyiv on Monday, to mark the third anniversary of Russia's 2022 full-scale invasion. Spain's prime minister, Pedro Sánchez; the European Council president, António Costa; and the European commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, are expected.
  The US president's rambling personal attacks have galvanised support for Zelenskyy among Ukrainians, including people who were previously disenchanted. A new opinion poll found 63% approved of him – a figure many times higher than the 4% rating falsely claimed this week by Trump and Musk.
  Prominent Ukrainian journalist Kristina Berdynskykh said: "After three years of full-scale war, Ukrainians are tired, nervous and often quarrel with each other. But I feel that now everyone will unite again. This always happens when Ukrainians feel an existential threat."
  Trump has echoed Kremlin propaganda by claiming Zelenskyy refuses to hold elections and is therefore illegitimate. Under martial law, elections are not allowed. Few Ukrainians support the idea of a poll, at a time when millions have fled abroad, a fifth of the country is occupied by Russia, and while soldiers are fighting and dying on the frontline.
  On Friday more than 130 Ukrainian civil society organisations said Russia's war of aggression made it impossible for Ukraine to hold elections – both for the presidency and parliament. In a statement pushing back on Trump's remarks, they said that government legitimacy was "the exclusive prerogative of the Ukrainian people".
  The NGOs said there was a consensus among both ruling and opposition political parties, as well as from the general public, that polls could only be held at least six months after a genuine ceasefire. This would give authorities time to prepare the electoral process, and to rebuild damaged infrastructure, they said.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Gen Keith Kellogg as the US envoy to Ukraine, confirming both his name and the described role.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Keith Kellogg" and refers to him as "Gen Keith Kellogg, the US envoy to Ukraine". This matches the target entity name and description (US envoy to Ukraine).
reasoning.statement_detection: Kellogg is quoted in the article: "he said he had had 'extensive and positive discussions' with Zelenskyy" and "A long and intense day with the senior leadership of Ukraine,". These are direct statements attributed to him, confirming he is making statements.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q27916194 is a military officer with a field of work that includes diplomacy, and has held the position of United States National Security Advisor. This aligns with the article’s description of a general serving as the US envoy to Ukraine. Candidate Q111176633 is a Michigan state politician, which does not fit the diplomatic/military context. Therefore Q27916194 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q27916194 holds a senior U.S. government position (National Security Advisor) and is a military officer, giving him the authority to act as an envoy and to make statements about Ukraine. The article’s context of him speaking about diplomatic relations supports this authority.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a U.S. military officer who has served as National Security Advisor to be appointed as the US envoy to Ukraine and to make public statements about Ukrainian leadership. The statements in the article are consistent with the role and responsibilities of such an envoy.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity is present in the article, is making statements, and the candidate Q27916194 matches the name, occupation, and diplomatic role described. No other candidate fits the context, so Q27916194 is the correct Wikidata ID for both presence and statement attribution.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Gen Keith Kellogg as the US envoy to Ukraine, confirming both his name and the described role.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Gen Keith Kellogg as the US envoy to Ukraine, confirming both his name and the described role.

political_party.name: Reform Party of the United States of America

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Donald Trump" multiple times and identifies him as the "US president". The reference is unambiguous and matches the target entity’s name and description.
reasoning.statement_detection: Several direct quotes are attributed to Trump: "I don't think he's very important to be in meetings," Trump told Fox News, and earlier statements such as claiming Ukraine was to blame for the war and calling Zelenskyy a "dictator". These are clear instances of the entity making statements.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q22686 (Donald Trump) matches the name, description, and current position of US president. The other candidates (Q27947481, Q3713655, Q23000825) are either a physician or relatives and do not fit the context of a US president. Thus Q22686 is the sole viable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the office of President of the United States (2025‑present per data), giving him the authority to make public statements about foreign policy and Ukraine.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: The statements attributed to Trump are consistent with the role of a national leader addressing international affairs. The content (criticizing Ukraine, referencing negotiations) aligns with typical presidential commentary, making the attribution plausible.
reasoning.final_justification: All evidence confirms that the target entity is present, is making statements, and the best matching Wikidata candidate is Q22686. No other candidate satisfies the description or context.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

Elon Musk.name: Elon Musk

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly names Elon Musk as the world’s richest man leading Trump’s governmental overhaul and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

input_details.name: Elon Musk
input_details.description: The world's richest man, leading Trump's governmental overhaul

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Elon Musk" and describes him as "the world's richest man" who is "leading Trump's huge governmental overhaul". The name matches the Wikidata entity name. The description in the article aligns with the Wikidata description of Musk as a prominent entrepreneur and public figure, and the phrase "world's richest man" is a widely recognized attribute of Musk. No other individual named Elon Musk is mentioned, and the contextual clues (wealth, public statements) match the Wikidata profile. Therefore, the entity is present and identifiable.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The article attributes direct statements to Elon Musk: "said Trump was right to leave Zelenskyy out of peace talks" and "accused Ukraine's leader of running a 'massive graft machine'". These are clear attributions of speech to the entity.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: While it is plausible for Elon Musk to make public statements about international politics, the claim that he is "leading Trump's huge governmental overhaul" is inconsistent with his known roles (entrepreneur, investor, not a political office holder). Thus, the specific claim about leading the overhaul is implausible, but the quoted statements themselves are plausible for a high-profile public figure.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: The article's assertion that Musk is leading Trump's governmental overhaul contradicts the Wikidata profile, which lists no political or civil servant positions for him. This is a factual inconsistency, but it does not affect the identity match.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly names Elon Musk as the world’s richest man leading Trump’s governmental overhaul and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly names Elon Musk as the world’s richest man leading Trump’s governmental overhaul and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

position_held.name: Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces of Ukraine

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Volodymyr Zelenskyy as the Ukrainian president, confirming both the name and the description.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article repeatedly mentions "Zelenskyy" and refers to him as the Ukrainian president, matching the Wikidata description "President of Ukraine since 2019". The name appears as "Voldymyr Zelenskyy" in one instance, which is a common transliteration variant but clearly refers to the same individual. Contextual clues—his role as president, references to his national security team, and his involvement in negotiations—align with the Wikidata profile (politician, president, Supreme Commander). No conflicting information about a different person with the same name is present.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Zelenskyy is explicitly quoted and attributed with statements: "Zelenskyy prompted Trump's ire by observing that the US president lived in a Kremlin 'disinformation bubble'", "Late last year, Zelenskyy floated the idea of a partnership with the US", and "Zelenskyy declined to sign the document without US security guarantees". These are clear attributions of speech to the individual.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: All statements are consistent with Zelenskyy's role as president and his public engagement in diplomatic and political matters. The content (criticizing the US president, proposing partnerships, refusing agreements without guarantees) is entirely plausible for a head of state.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article's depiction of Zelenskyy and the Wikidata entity. The only discrepancy is a minor spelling variation, which does not affect identity.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Volodymyr Zelenskyy as the Ukrainian president, confirming both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Volodymyr Zelenskyy as the Ukrainian president, confirming both the name and the description.

This aligns perfectly with the article’s reference to a White House national security adviser named Mike Waltz. The other candidate (Q95813934) is an actor named Mike Waltze and does not match the description or context.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q55386653 held the official role of National Security Advisor, giving him the authority to comment on U.S. foreign policy and Ukraine negotiations. The statement in the article is consistent with the responsibilities of that office.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the White House national security adviser to publicly comment on Ukraine’s potential deal with the U.S., especially in a news context. The attribution is straightforward and unambiguous.
reasoning.final_justification: The article contains a clear mention of Mike Waltz as the White House national security adviser who made a statement. Candidate Q55386653 matches the name, title, and description exactly, and the statement attribution is credible. Therefore, Q55386653 is the correct Wikidata ID for both presence and statement attribution.
